title: Figma Unveils AI-Powered Erase, Isolate, and Expand Tools for Seamless Canvas Editing

paragraphs.content: Figma has launched three new AI-powered image-editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—integrated into a consolidated contextual toolbar on the Figma canvas. These features allow designers to remove unwanted elements, separate subjects for repositioning or effects, and extend image backgrounds to new aspect ratios without exporting to external apps like Photoshop. The tools emphasize precision through improved lasso selection and operate without text prompts, targeting granular edits common in design workflows.

paragraphs.content: Figma positions these updates as a productivity boost for marketers and teams iterating on mockups, banners, and product shots directly in Figma Design and Draw. The toolbar also centralizes prior capabilities like Crop and Remove background for faster access. Availability is limited to Full seats on Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plans with AI enabled, with expansion planned for more products next year.

sections.title: New Tools Transform In-Canvas Precision Editing

paragraphs.content: **Erase object** enables users to select and remove elements via an enhanced lasso tool, with AI filling the space to match background continuity. **Isolate object** separates a subject for movement or adjustments like lighting, shadow, color, or focus while preserving image characteristics. **Expand image** synthesizes plausible extensions beyond original borders, ideal for reformatting square shots into landscape banners without distortion.

paragraphs.content: Figma's blog highlights these as prompt-free tools, distinguishing them from generative models by focusing on selection-driven control. The consolidated toolbar streamlines access, placing frequent actions like background removal prominently. Designers report reduced friction in mockup iterations, avoiding export-import loops for minor tweaks.

sections.title: Industry Catches Up as Figma Matches Adobe and Canva

paragraphs.content: TechCrunch notes Figma is catching up to rivals like Adobe and Canva, which offered object removal years earlier, but differentiates through seamless canvas integration. ContentGrip emphasizes workflow gains for marketers repurposing assets across formats without design team handoffs. Early demos show strong results for simple scenes, though complex textures may challenge fill quality.

Figma plans broader rollout across products in 2026, alongside its AI suite integrating Gemini 3 Pro and GPT Image 1 for generation tasks. Observers anticipate independent benchmarks to test edge cases like fine hair or occlusions. The launch aligns with industry trends embedding AI edits into collaborative tools.
